title: Broken extensions (Gemini Code Assist, GitLens) on WSL2 after updating
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No - VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (user setup) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Version: 1.103.2 (user setup) Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755 Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Hi! Really hate to file such a vague issue, but I've not been able to scope it down more. I have 2 extensions that worked fine: - Gemini Code Assist - GitLens but after applying the last update, they both appear in a perpetual "loading" state. Only happens on WSL2, on local they work fine. Both are installed on the remote. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VSCode wsl 2 remote 2. Open GitLens tab Notes: - Using bisect, extensions are broken even if they're the only ones active - I see nothing relevant on the extension host / extension host (remote) Outputs - "Reload window" doesn't help - Rebooting PC doesn't help

title: Preserve case in multicursor replace command
body:
# Problem
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/106502.

Reading through the issue it seems the main problem involves preserving the case of the first letter of a variable name when executing a replace command on multiple case-insensitive selections of that word.

# Solution
To fix this, when defining the replace command for a given selection, we can check the case of the first letter of the text to replace, and update the case of the character that will replace it accordingly.

So if we have selections `"value"` and `"Value"`, and type `"a"` (while typing `array`), when composing the replace command for `"Value"` we see that it starts with a capital and replace the selection with `"A"`, not with `"a"`.

For now this logic is only applied in the case of multiple selections.

# Testing
Given
```
const [value, setValue] = useState();
```

Select `"value"` and `"Value"`, and then type `"array"`.

Expected result
```
const [array, setArray] = useState();
```

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2a3f2716-1785-45f5-9ff7-ae37d0e482cd

Note: it might make sense to make this feature opt-in, whether through some setting or a dedicated button as was suggested in the issue. I'm open to suggestions. 🙏

I have had this dotfile for a while, in my repo. Please fix this <3 i love you

```bash
# /usr/local/.bashrc

# fix: bash in VS Code Terminal

title: There is no way to control whether it should be executed in a new terminal or the current terminal

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Type: Bug Type: Bug Often, when executing commands in agent mode, they should execute the command in the currently executed window, but instead they open a new terminal window, rendering the previous command useless. For example: First execution: cd abc && dotnet build Second execution: dotnet run (A new window will open, but the directory is the workspace root. However, executing this command without a specified project directory will be invalid.) The intended behavior is for the command to continue executing directly in the previously opened window. Another scenario is the opposite: For example: First execution: dotnet run # This starts the application normally. Second execution: netstat -an | findstr ":5000|:7000" This command will execute directly in the shell of the first execution, causing it to terminate the running service. The intended behavior is to execute this command in a new terminal window. The above situations are very common. I really don't understand how Copilot Chat controls whether to use the current window or a new one. Furthermore, it doesn't know which window it's in at all; it needs to run the pwd command to determine it, which I find incredibly stupid. This massive command execution wastes a lot of time. Is there a reliable solution to this problem? Is it possible to provide a drop-down list when executing a command, allowing the user to choose whether to use a new window or the current one, or whether to use PowerShell or MinGW64 (even if the default is set, it often doesn't follow it). title: Título: Mejorar accesibilidad: opción de copiar sugerencias de código / Title: Improve Accessibility: Add Option to Copy Code Suggestions
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Título: Mejorar accesibilidad: opción de copiar sugerencias de código 

Hola equipo de VS Code,

Actualmente, las sugerencias de código (tooltips, hints, completions) aparecen en color celeste y no permiten copiar su contenido. Esto dificulta el uso para personas con movilidad reducida, ya que seleccionar y copiar manualmente es complicado o imposible.

Sugiero incluir un botón o atajo para copiar directamente el contenido de las sugerencias, mejorando así la accesibilidad y experiencia de uso.

Gracias por considerar esta mejora.

Atentamente,
Ferdinando Santangelo


Title: Improve Accessibility: Add Option to Copy Code Suggestions

Issue Body:
Hello VS Code team,

Currently, code suggestions (tooltips, hints, completions) appear in light blue and do not allow copying their content. This makes it difficult for users with reduced mobility, as manually selecting and copying is challenging or impossible.

I suggest adding a button or shortcut to directly copy the content of suggestions, which would improve accessibility and overall user experience.

Thank you for considering this improvement.

Sincerely,
Ferdinando Santangelo

milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Following instructions provided here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262107#issuecomment-3214159622 for a similar issue. If you ask Copilot to do anything that requires more than one terminal command, it hangs on the second command and does not complete. The command itself may complete in the terminal, but Copilot does not get any kind of signal saying the command completed and knows to stop, or continue with the next operation. This is very consistent. For example, when asking something like this. > In this project there is a test folder. However there are test files that have been created outside of that folder and are sitting in the root src folder. > > Examine the test_* files, > 1. For each of them move then into the tests folder overwriting any existing files with the same name > 2. Change any internal relative references so that the tests will work from the tests folder. > 3. Update your settings so that in the future ALL test files are created in the tests folder. It executed a command to remove the files in the src folder because they were empty duplicates. `cd /home/------/code/GitHubMonitor && rm test_commit_diff.py test_company_detection.py test_search.py test_search_both.py` This executes fine, and then Copilot continues. On the second command where it went to check for remaining files in the root folder, it executed the command and hung. `cd /home/------/code/GitHubMonitor && ls test_*.py 2>/dev/null || echo "No test files in root directory"` It is very consistent about hanging on the second terminal command it executes regardless of what it is doing. This is just an example of that. - Copilot Chat Extension Version: Copilot Pro+ v 0.30.3 - VS Code Version: 1.103.2 - OS Version: Windows 11 Version 24H2 (OS Build 26100.4946) - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent mode - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Connet 4 - Logs: (see attached screen shots) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Copilot Chat 2. Create any prompt that will require more than one terminal command such as the one above. 3. Wait for it to hang on the second or subsequent terminal execution

title: Implement copilot_listCodeUsages tool with fallback from document to workspace symbols
body:
The `#usages` / `copilot_listCodeUsages` tool was essentially broken because it would fail to find symbols when they weren't present in the document outline (document symbols). This commonly occurred when:

1. The symbol was defined in a different file than the one being analyzed
2. The language server hadn't fully indexed the current file's symbols
3. The symbol was part of external dependencies or libraries

The original implementation would:
1. Call `getDocumentSymbols` for the specified file path
2. If no match found, give up with "Symbol XYZ cannot be found"
3. Never attempt to search the broader workspace

This fix implements the proper fallback behavior:
1. First tries `getDocumentSymbols` for the specified file (if provided)
2. **When symbol not found in document symbols, falls back to `getWorkspaceSymbols`**
3. Uses the found symbol location to call `getDefinitions`, `getReferences`, and `getImplementations`
4. Returns comprehensive usage information in markdown format

## Key Changes

- **New tool implementation**: Created `listCodeUsagesTool.ts` with the `copilot_listCodeUsages` tool
- **Proper fallback logic**: Implements workspace symbol search when document symbols fail
- **#usages syntax support**: Added `toolReferenceName: 'usages'` and `canBeReferencedInPrompt: true`
- **Comprehensive error handling**: Provides informative feedback instead of generic failures
- **Service integration**: Uses VS Code's `ILanguageFeaturesService` and `ITextModelService` for symbol resolution
- **Built-in registration**: Tool is automatically available as a built-in tool

## Example Usage

Users can now use `#usages symbolName` in Copilot Chat and the tool will:
- Search the active file first
- Fall back to workspace-wide search if needed  
- Return definitions, references, and implementations with file locations and line numbers

This fix ensures the tool works reliably across different programming languages (TypeScript, JavaScript, C++, etc.) by leveraging the appropriate language service providers.

Fixes #262418.

title: Add more fig specs
body:
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/263167

This pulls in a lot of specs from upstream. Some of the bigger ones are gh, docker/docker-compose and ruff. This is mostly really safe but there are some parts of this that results in command execution. I reviewed all the specs for troublesome scripts/generators, removing any that look concerning.

To make this more sustainable in the long run it would be so much better if the generators that can execute code were separated from the plain text completions. There aren't that many generators but they are higher risk.

cc @meganrogge

title: Keep "Panel Header" Visible When Minimized (Avoid "Vanishing Panel")

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: layout
labels.description: General VS Code workbench layout issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When the bottom `panel` is minimized, it disappears completely off-screen.
- New users may assume that the `panel` has been **closed**.
- Restoring it requires **pixel-perfect mouse placement** at the bottom edge.

### Proposed Feature
When minimizing the `panel`
- Keep a thin **header strip** visible at the bottom.

### Why this helps
- Improves discoverability (`panel` never **vanishes**).
- Makes restoring easier from the `panel header`.

### Example
The current behaviour of the `panel` (look closely at the bottom):

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3cb86747-dcbb-47e7-b9eb-99b6c404c468

The way how the `panel header` remains visible in this `html` prototype previewed in VS code:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d792bef9-dd5c-4faa-8ae4-11e5f414241d

title: Copilot can't see file changes in "Agent" mode

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: where can I see it? - VS Code Version: 1.103.2 - OS Version: MacOS Monterey 12.7.6 (Darwin x64 21.6.0) - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT 4.1 - Logs: Steps to Reproduce: 1. open simple hello world *.go file in workspace 2. select "Agent" mode in Copilot 3. Ask it "what the code is" 4. It will show content of the file in a chat box 5. Change something in source code 6. Ask same question again 7. It will show same content (without changes) 8. Ask couple more times. It will show outdated content every single time 9. Switch to "Ask" mode 10. Now each time you change anything in source code, it shows you the updated version of the file in chat window upon same question. When I asked Copilot directly why does it work this way, this is what it told: why in agent mode you can't see changes in files? In agent mode, I can only see the file content you provide through attachments or direct input. I don’t have real-time access to your filesystem or automatic updates from your editor. If you make changes, you need to send the updated file or excerpt for me to see and respond to the latest version. even in workspace you can't see file contents? Correct, I cannot automatically see or access file contents in your workspace. I can only view and respond to code or files that you share with me directly through attachments or pasted excerpts. If you want me to review or modify a file, please provide its content or relevant sections. but why in "Ask" mode you see file updates then? In "Ask" mode, your IDE (VS Code) sends the current file content or your selection directly to me with each request. This allows me to see the latest updates you make before asking a question. In "Agent" mode, I rely only on what you explicitly share, so I don’t automatically receive file changes unless you attach or paste them. The difference is how your IDE communicates file context to me. -------------------------- This is weird, why make "Agent" mode in such a way that it doesn't see updates in files, which makes it pretty useless. Is this a bug? ## Screenshots Initial answer (everything is right): Added some changes (exclamations in 3rd line), asked again, it showed updated content, everything's fine: Removed 3rd line, asked again, it showed outdated content with 3rd line:

title: Incomplete copy & paste

title: Improvements to Copilot Chat Usability (History Navigation & Mentions)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->


I've been using the Copilot Chat integration in VS Code extensively, and while it’s already a great experience, there are a couple of **huge usability pain points** that significantly impact productivity. Fixing these would drastically improve the chat UX and make it much more user-friendly.

---

### 1. Arrow-Up Key Behavior in Chat Input

**Problem:**
When I’m typing in the chat input and press **Arrow Up** while on the first line/character, instead of just moving the cursor to the start of the input, the entire input disappears and I’m taken into my chat history.

* This causes me to **lose my current draft**, which is extremely frustrating when I just wanted to move the cursor.
* I personally don’t see the benefit of prioritizing history recall over safe editing of the current message.

**Proposed Solutions:**

* Default behavior: pressing **Arrow Up at the first line should move the cursor to the beginning of the text**, not clear the draft.
* If history recall is important, it could be triggered via a **modifier key** (e.g. `Alt+ArrowUp`), ensuring both features can coexist without interfering.

---

### 2. Copy-Pasting Mentions in Chat

**Problem:**
When I copy a previous prompt that includes **file mentions (using `#file:filename.tsx`)** and paste it into a new chat session:

* The pasted mention is not recognized as a file anymore.
* The extra metadata (like relative file path) is lost.
* This makes reusing prompts across chats almost impossible, which is a huge limitation.

**Why this matters:**

* Often I want to retry a prompt with a fresh session or a different model.
* Losing file context on paste means I have to manually re-mention every file, which kills productivity.

**Suggested Behavior (inspired by \[Cline experience]):**

* When copying & pasting, mentions should **retain full metadata**, including the relative path to the project root.
* Example: Instead of just `#file:index.ts`, it should carry something like `#file:src/components/index.ts` to disambiguate files with the same name.
* This way, prompts can be safely reused in different chats.

---

### 3. Mention Syntax Improvements (`#` vs `@`)

**Observation:**

* Currently, VS Code uses `#` for mentions.
* Competing tools like Cline, Cursor and Windsurf use `@`, which feels more natural for many users.

**Suggestion:**

* Support both `#` and `@` as mention prefixes.
* This would make the system more familiar to users coming from other tools and avoid conflicts with files named `#something`.
* Optional: distinguish semantics (e.g. `@` for files, `#` for symbols), but even just supporting both would be a big win.

title: Issue #210694 add hoverforeground and hoverbackground to activity bars
body:
This pull request introduces customizable hover colors for the side, top, and bottom activity bars.

The changes address issue #210694 (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/210694), which requested the ability to set hoverForeground and hoverBackground for a more visible hover state on activity bar icons. This implementation allows users to define specific colors in their settings to improve the discoverability and accessibility of the UI.

I've added the necessary color token properties to the activity bar's color contribution points to enable this feature. @benibenj (https://github.com/benibenj)

Testing:
I have verified that the new color settings work as expected and do not introduce any regressions. The hover state now correctly reflects the colors specified in the user's settings.


Modified Files Summary

1. Theme Color Definition [src/vs/workbench/common/theme.ts]
- Define new theme color tokens:
  - `ACTIVITY_BAR_HOVER_FOREGROUND`
  - `ACTIVITY_BAR_HOVER_BACKGROUND`
  - `ACTIVITY_BAR_TOP_HOVER_FOREGROUND`
  - `ACTIVITY_BAR_TOP_HOVER_BACKGROUND`

2. Activity Bar: Theming + Wiring [src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/activitybar/activitybarPart.ts]
- Register new hover tokens in theme registry
- Map hover tokens to CSS variables for stylesheet consumption
- Wire hover colors into composite bar configuration

3. Activity Bar CSS (Hover Styles) [src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/activitybar/media/activityaction.css]
- Apply hover styles using new CSS variables:
  - `--vscode-activityBar-hoverForeground`
  - `--vscode-activityBar-hoverBackground`
- Integrate hover states with existing active/focus styling

4. Sidebar: Theming Integration [src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/sidebar/sidebarPart.ts]
- Reference top-position hover tokens for consistency:
  - `ACTIVITY_BAR_TOP_HOVER_FOREGROUND`
  - `ACTIVITY_BAR_TOP_HOVER_BACKGROUND`
- Ensure sidebar hover behavior aligns with activity bar when positioned at top or bottom

5. Sidebar CSS (Hover Styles) [src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/sidebar/media/sidebarpart.css]
- Apply hover styling using activity bar CSS variables
- Maintain visual consistency between sidebar and activity bar hover states

6. Stylelint Allowlist [build/lib/stylelint/vscode-known-variables.json]
- Add CSS custom properties to prevent lint errors:
  - `--vscode-activityBar-hoverForeground`
  - `--vscode-activityBar-hoverBackground`

Usage
user's settings:

settings.json
```
{
  "workbench.activityBar.location": "default", // "top" or "bottom"
  "workbench.colorCustomizations": {
    // Left Activity Bar 
    "activityBar.hoverForeground": "#ff0000", 
    "activityBar.hoverBackground": "#00ff00",

    // Top Activity Bar 
    "activityBarTop.hoverForeground": "#0000ff", 
    "activityBarTop.hoverBackground": "#ffff00" 
    } 
}
```

title: WSL Command Execution - Every Second Command Not Received
body: Description: # Problem When using Claude Sonnet 4 with MCP (Model Context Protocol) to execute commands in WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux), every second command execution fails to be received or processed properly. This creates an inconsistent and unreliable experience when trying to perform sequential operations. Environment OS: Windows 11 latest with WSL2 WSL Distribution: [Kali Linux with kex server] MCP Version: latest as of 09:00 UTC. Date: 24-08-2025(dd-mm-yyyy) Client: Claude Sonnet 4 (Agent) Terminal: WSL terminal # Steps to Reproduce Execute a command in WSL through MCP (e.g., ls) Execute a second command immediately after (e.g., pwd) (Cancel request for infinite loop) Execute a third command (e.g., whoami) Observe that commands 2, 4, 6, etc. are not received/processed # Expected Behavior All commands should be executed sequentially and consistently through the MCP interface without any being dropped or ignored. # Actual Behavior Every second command appears to be dropped or not received by the MCP system, causing: Incomplete command sequences Broken workflows Need to retry commands manually Inconsistent development experience # Example Session ``` Command 1: ls ✅ Works Command 2: pwd ❌ Not received (Had to cancel) Command 3: make ✅ Works Command 4: ./sendra-desktop ❌ Not received ``` Additional Context This issue specifically occurs when working with WSL through MCP and appears to be a pattern rather than random failures. The commands that aren't received would work fine if executed directly in the WSL terminal. # Possible Causes - Race condition in command processing - Buffer/queue management issue - WSL-specific communication timing - MCP command parsing inconsistency

title: fix: memory leak in codelens controller
Feature Request: Add keyboard shortcut to switch between Extension Development Host and main VS Code window

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: extensions-development
labels.description: Issues for developing extensions

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
Currently, when developing extensions, we constantly need to switch back and forth between the main VS Code window (where we edit the extension code) and the "Extension Development Host" window (where the extension is running).

Problem:
- The Extension Development Host is not referenced as a target in `keybindings.json`.
- There is no built-in keyboard shortcut to jump between the two windows.
- On macOS, Cmd+` only cycles through *all* windows of VS Code, which is inefficient when having multiple projects opened.

Impact:
- Extension developers need to switch thousands of times per day.
- Relying on Cmd+Tab or macOS Mission Control slows down iteration drastically.

Feature request:
- Add a dedicated command (e.g. `workbench.action.toggleExtensionHostWindow`) that focuses the Extension Development Host if open, or cycles between the main VS Code and the Host.
- Make it available in `keybindings.json` so developers can assign their preferred shortcut.

This would massively improve extension development workflow.

title: The `fetch` tool fails to capture table headers

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: fetch-tool
labels.description: Issues concerning the fetch internal tool and web extracting service

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Name: GitHub Copilot Chat
Id: GitHub.copilot-chat
Description: AI chat features powered by Copilot
Version: 0.31.2025082213
Publisher: GitHub
VS Marketplace Link: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.copilot-chat

Version: 1.104.0-insider
Commit: df6568066e88d67331cec7a12a34bdef058fb62b
Date: 2025-08-22T17:09:01.208Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Tell the Agent to fetch https://www.htmltables.io/tags/thead and output it.
2. The headers in the first table example, i.e. `Header 1` and `Header 2`, are missing.

When `<th>` or `<thead>` is used to define table headers, the `fetch` tool omits them. `processTableNode` cannot properly handle such cases. See:

- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/e72993050e03023966efb1cfbe90fa92f0fa39de/src/vs/platform/webContentExtractor/electron-main/cdpAccessibilityDomain.ts#L408

[tool_fetch_webpage_2e0f7db5-29c2-4510-8bac-c90d1e2560af.copilotmd](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21955427/tool_fetch_webpage_2e0f7db5-29c2-4510-8bac-c90d1e2560af.copilotmd)

Note that headers are also omitted when only the `<th>` tag is used. For example: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Elements/table#basic_table

body:
Type: Bug ■MOZCで日本語入力ができなくなった こんにちは、開発チームの皆さん。VSCodeとCopilotの組み合わせは最高ですね。 「半角/全角」あるいはubuntuのシステムトレイから「日本語(Mozc)」を選択するが、VSCodeで日本語が使用できなくなってしまった。 それまで使えていたが、下記のコマンド実行後にVSCodeでだけ、日本語入力が使えない状況になってしまった。 ■やってしまったこと Nemoをインストール sudo apt install nemo locale -a sudo update-locale LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LANGUAGE="en_US:en" LANG=C xdg-user-dirs-gtk-update ！問題が発生！ ■復旧のためにやったこと#１ その後、下記のコマンドを実行したが改善しない sudo update-locale LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8 LANGUAGE="ja_JP:ja" ibus restart 　→改善しない 　 ■復旧のためにやったこと#２ アプリセンターからcodeを削除し,下記のフォルダを削除 rm -rf ~/.vscode/ その後、再びcodeの再インストール 　→改善しない ■復旧のためにやったこと#３ 拡張機能：Copilot, Copilot Chat, Japanese Language Pack for Visual Studio Codeをインストール sudo update-locale LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8 LANGUAGE="ja_JP:ja" ibus restart 　→改善しない このレポートは、他のエディタを使って日本語で作成したものを貼り付けています。 ありがとう。 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.14.0-28-generic snap Modes:

title: Chat: Cannot enable GPT-5 mini
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

Just tried to use GPT-5 mini on my desktop for the first time and am hitting an issue where it's not possible to approve / move past the "Enable GPT-5 mini" dialog. It just keeps being shown again and again.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: `Insiders 1.104`
- OS Version: Linux Bluefin V42 (based on Fedora Silverblue 42)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a brand new instance of VS Code (Insiders?)
2. Open Chat
3. Select GPT-5 mini
4. Type / send any prompt 
5. See "Enable GPT-5 mini" dialog
6. Click "Enable" button on dialog
7. Rather than enabling the dialog will be re-rendered and keep re-rendering every time you click the enable button
